title: Disproportionality analysis
text: life cycle medicinal product, knowledge safety profile continues accumulate post market introduction. Adverse event reports collected spontaneous reporting play instrumental part development. Adverse event report databases often cover wide range drugs events, beyond can feasibly monitored manual work. Disproportionality analysis thus often used highlight drug-event-combinations potential interest qualitative manual case--case assessment. pvda package provides three disproportionality estimators: proportional reporting rate (PRR), reporting odds ratio (ROR) information component (IC). takes report level data input, outputs estimates drug-event-combination, possibly stratified variable interest, e.g. age group /sex.

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: workhorse package function da. da-function takes patient level data data frame input (drug_event_df) produces estimates summary counts demonstrated . drug_event_df simulated data set drugs named Drug_A - Drug_Z events Event_1 - Event_1000. details simulation documented data object (execute ?df_drug_event).
code: da_1 <-    drug_event_df |>   da()

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: da-function examine passed data set column names contained passed parameter list “df_colnames”. default column names “report_id”, “drug” “event”. rename report-id column “drug_event_df” need specify new name call da, shown :
code: da_1 <-   drug_event_df |>    dplyr::rename(reportID = report_id) |>    da(df_colnames = list(report_id = "reportID"))

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: ‘da_1’ object can passed summary print function.   (Technical note: printing colors console easily reproduced within vignette , provide screenshots applicable. )
code: summary(da_1) print(da_1, n=3)

what: Passing a correctly structured input data
title: Disproportionality analysis
text: input data needs report-level format. every line data frame corresponds drug-event pair specific report. drug_event_df-example data, first three rows drug_event_df report, report_id = 1. first row reports Drug_D adverse event named Event_5.next three rows another report, instance drug B reported two different events, event 15 event 33. can ignore group-column now.
code: drug_event_df[1:6, ] ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   report_id drug   event    group ##       <int> <chr>  <chr>    <dbl> ## 1         1 Drug_A Event_23     1 ## 2         1 Drug_D Event_6      1 ## 3         1 Drug_E Event_8      1 ## 4         1 Drug_I Event_9      1 ## 5         2 Drug_B Event_2      0 ## 6         2 Drug_G Event_13     0

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: covenience, output object da list class “da” containing two objects, results (“da_df”) input parameters (“input_params”). point might want extract results input parameters list, demonstrate alternatives:
code: names(da_1) ## [1] "da_df"        "input_params" # Different ways of extracting the results data frame # da_1$da_df # da_1[['da_df']] # da_1 |> purrr::pluck("da_df")

what: How to run a subgroup analysis?
title: Disproportionality analysis
text: da function builds comparator passed data, e.g. prr excluding drug interest comparator, sometimes referred background. implies subgroup analysis e.g. specific age groups can achieved creating new data frame subgroup interest, passing da. exhaustive grouping required, one can provide grouping variable group_by da. executes call da grouping return results single data frame. grouping instance age groups, sex, countries, regions combination thereof, needs passed single variable (character numeric). drug_event_df contains two groups, column named “group”. can pass “group” group_by parameter df_colnames . output note third column “group”, .e. column name passed. also note drug-event-pairs kept together, e.g. first second row contains drug-event-combination, “Drug_Z” “Event_1”. simplify comparisons within drug-event-pair across different groups, e.g. pattern seen across males females. ordering drug-events output made averaging selected disproportionality estimate (parameter sort_by), .e. top two rows highest average “ic2.5”.
code: drug_event_df |>    head() ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   report_id drug   event    group ##       <int> <chr>  <chr>    <dbl> ## 1         1 Drug_A Event_23     1 ## 2         1 Drug_D Event_6      1 ## 3         1 Drug_E Event_8      1 ## 4         1 Drug_I Event_9      1 ## 5         2 Drug_B Event_2      0 ## 6         2 Drug_G Event_13     0 da_grouped <-    drug_event_df |>    da(df_colnames = list(group_by="group"))   print(da_grouped$da_df) ## # A tibble: 1,808 × 24 ##    drug   event   group   obs exp_rrr ic2.5    ic ic97.5 exp_prr prr2.5   prr ##    <chr>  <chr>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> ##  1 Drug_Z Event_1     0    45    26.5  0.3   0.75   1.14    23.4   1.54  1.92 ##  2 Drug_Z Event_1     1    43    29.1  0.09  0.56   0.96    26.5   1.28  1.63 ##  3 Drug_Z Event_2     0    33    24.6 -0.12  0.42   0.87    23.2   1.07  1.42 ##  4 Drug_Z Event_2     1    42    27.8  0.12  0.59   0.99    25.1   1.3   1.67 ##  5 Drug_V Event_2     0    34    26.0 -0.14  0.38   0.82    24.6   1.04  1.38 ##  6 Drug_V Event_2     1    46    31.0  0.12  0.56   0.95    27.8   1.3   1.66 ##  7 Drug_V Event_1     0    40    28.0  0.03  0.51   0.92    25.8   1.21  1.55 ##  8 Drug_V Event_1     1    42    32.4 -0.1   0.37   0.77    30.3   1.07  1.38 ##  9 Drug_U Event_2     0    42    31.5 -0.06  0.41   0.81    29.1   1.11  1.44 ## 10 Drug_U Event_2     1    37    26.8 -0.04  0.46   0.89    24.9   1.14  1.49 ## # ℹ 1,798 more rows ## # ℹ 13 more variables: prr97.5 <dbl>, exp_ror <dbl>, ror2.5 <dbl>, ror <dbl>, ## #   ror97.5 <dbl>, n_drug <int>, n_event <int>, n_tot <int>, n_event_prr <int>, ## #   n_tot_prr <int>, b <int>, c <int>, d <int>

what: How are drug-event pairs occurrings several times in one report counted?
title: Disproportionality analysis
text: drug-event pair occurs several times one report, contributes counts . , observed count five means five different reports containing drug-event-pair (least ). due single report containing drug-event pair five times due repeated events data quality issues. demonstrated , duplicate first row drug_event_df still arrive observed count 1.
code: first_row <- drug_event_df[1,]  first_row |>    dplyr::bind_rows(first_row) |>    da() |>    purrr::pluck("da_df") |>    dplyr::pull(obs) ## [1] 1

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: Detailed formulas PRR, RRR IC documented within function ( “?prr”, “?rrr”, “?ic”), overall one can note expected counts derived contingency table exposed drug, experience adverse event. sample used contingency table data frame passed da function. See also grouping parameter.

what: Where is exp_ic in the output, or what is exp_prr?
title: Disproportionality analysis
text: common question regards output column names, ic preceded “exp_prr”. information component uses expected count Relative Reporting Rate (RRR), perhaps well known pharmacovigilande community.
code: # Note the fourth column name: drug_event_df |>    da() |>    purrr::pluck("da_df") |>    dplyr::select(drug:ic97.5) |>    print(n=1) ## # A tibble: 1,306 × 7 ##   drug   event     obs exp_rrr ic2.5    ic ic97.5 ##   <chr>  <chr>   <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> ## 1 Drug_Z Event_1    88    55.6  0.34  0.66   0.94 ## # ℹ 1,305 more rows

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: function da several input parameters. One rule_of_N, default set 3, sometimes referred “rule three”. sets ROR PRR-values NA observed count less specified N. completeness, note default shrinkage IC acts built ‘rule 3’, (.e. shrinkage +0.5 prevents lower bound exceed 0 default significance level 95%).

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: function da parameter number_of_digits controls rounding non-count values output, including expected counts, uncertainty bounds point estimates.
code: drug_event_df |>   da(     rule_of_N = 3,     number_of_digits = 8   ) |> print(n = 3)

what: Can I use pvda to get IC, PRR or ROR, when I already have the observed and expected counts?
title: Disproportionality analysis
text: Yes, can calculate point estimates confidence credibility intervals specific drug-event-combination already number observed reports, required counts database total count, number reports exposure number reports event. can helpful instance quality check results, e.g. papers software. details specific input parameters, consult documentation function.

title: Disproportionality analysis
text: data.table-package (“dtplyr”) used fast execution. test execution speed made using vaers R package, available gitlab. vaers package contains data VAERS years 1990 - 2018, resulting 4 146 778 rows processed da pvda. Execution time regular laptop less 10 seconds.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Oskar Gauffin. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gauffin O (2024). pvda: Disproportionality Functions Pharmacovigilance. R package version 0.0.3, https://oskargauffin.github.io/pvda/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {pvda: Disproportionality Functions for Pharmacovigilance},   author = {Oskar Gauffin},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.3},   url = {https://oskargauffin.github.io/pvda/}, }

title: Disproportionality Functions for Pharmacovigilance
text: R package executing disproportionality analyses pharmacovigilance, using information component (IC), proportional reporting rate (PRR) reporting odds ratio (ROR).

title: Disproportionality Functions for Pharmacovigilance
code: # Install stable version from CRAN  install.packages("pvda")

title: Disproportionality Functions for Pharmacovigilance
text: run disproportionality analysis, pass adverse event report-level data (, drug_event_df) function da : Summary console output extract results data frame, access “da_df” list object: Print console output
code: library("pvda")  da1 <-  drug_event_df |>  da()  summary(da1) da_results <-  da1$da_df

what:
Add disproportionality estimates to data frame
with expected counts — add_disproportionality
title:
Add disproportionality estimates to data frame
with expected counts — add_disproportionality
text: Add disproportionality estimates data frame expected counts

title:
Add disproportionality estimates to data frame
with expected counts — add_disproportionality
code: add_disproportionality(   df = NULL,   df_syms = NULL,   da_estimators = c("ic", "prr", "ror"),   rule_of_N = 3,   conf_lvl = 0.95 )

title:
Add disproportionality estimates to data frame
with expected counts — add_disproportionality
text: df Intended use output tibble add_expected_counts. df_syms list built df_colnames conversion symbols. da_estimators Character vector specifying disproportionality estimators use, case need implemented options. Defaults c("ic", "prr", "ror"). rule_of_N Numeric value. Sets estimates ROR PRR NA observed counts strictly less passed value rule_of_N. Default value 3, 5 sometimes used liberal alternative. Set NULL want apply rule. conf_lvl Confidence level confidence credibility intervals. Default 0.95 (.e. 95 % confidence interval).

title:
Add disproportionality estimates to data frame
with expected counts — add_disproportionality
text: passed data frame disproportionality point interval estimates.

title: Produces expected counts — add_expected_counts
text: Produces various counts used disproportionality analysis.

title: Produces expected counts — add_expected_counts
code: add_expected_counts(   df = NULL,   df_colnames = NULL,   df_syms = NULL,   expected_count_estimators = c("rrr", "prr", "ror") )

title: Produces expected counts — add_expected_counts
text: df object possible convert data table, e.g. tibble data.frame, containing patient level reported drug-event-pairs. See header 'df object' details. df_colnames list column names use df. , point da 'report id'-column (report_id), 'drug name'-column (drug), 'adverse event'-column (event) optionally grouping column group_by calculate disproportionality across. See vignette details. df_syms list built df_colnames conversion symbols. expected_count_estimators character vector containing desired expected count estimators. Defaults c("rrr", "prr", "ror").

title: Produces expected counts — add_expected_counts
text: tibble containing various counts.

title: Produces expected counts — add_expected_counts
text: passed df (convertible ) data table least contain three  columns: report_id, drug event. data table contain one row  per reported drug-event-combination, .e. receiving single additional report  drug X event Y add one row table. single report  contained drug X event Y event Z, two rows added,  report_id drug rows. Column report_id must type  numeric character. Columns drug event must type character.  column group_by provided, can either numeric character.  can use df column names choosing, long  connect role name df_colnames-parameter.

title: apply_rule_of_N — apply_rule_of_N

title: Confidence intervals for Information Component (IC) — ci_for_ic
text: obs numeric vector observed counts, .e. number reports selected drug-event-combination. Note shrinkage (e.g. +0.5) added inside function included . exp numeric vector expected counts, .e. number reports expected given comparator background. Note shrinkage (e.g. +0.5) added inside function included . conf_lvl_probs probabilities posterior, based passed confidence level (conf_lvl) ic. instance, sgn_lvl = .95 ic used, quantiles extracted sgn_lvl_probs 0.025 0.975. shrinkage non-negative numeric value, added observed expected count. Default 0.5.

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
text: function da executes disproportionality analyses, .e. compares proportion reports specific adverse event drug, event proportion comparator based passed data frame. See vignette brief introduction disproportionality analysis. Furthermore, da supports three estimators: Information Component (IC), Proportional Reporting Rate (PRR) Reporting Odds Ratio (ROR).

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
code: da(   df = NULL,   df_colnames = list(report_id = "report_id", drug = "drug", event = "event", group_by =     NULL),   da_estimators = c("ic", "prr", "ror"),   sort_by = "ic",   number_of_digits = 2,   rule_of_N = 3,   conf_lvl = 0.95,   excel_path = NULL )

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
text: df object possible convert data table, e.g. tibble data.frame, containing patient level reported drug-event-pairs. See header 'df object' details. df_colnames list column names use df. , point da 'report id'-column (report_id), 'drug name'-column (drug), 'adverse event'-column (event) optionally grouping column group_by calculate disproportionality across. See vignette details. da_estimators Character vector specifying disproportionality estimators use, case need implemented options. Defaults c("ic", "prr", "ror"). sort_by output sorted descending order lower bound confidence/credibility interval passed da estimator. passed strings "da_estimators" accepted, default "ic". grouping variable passed, sorting made sample average across drug-event-combination (ignoring NAs). number_of_digits Round decimal columns specified precision, default two decimals. rule_of_N Numeric value. Sets estimates ROR PRR NA observed counts strictly less passed value rule_of_N. Default value 3, 5 sometimes used liberal alternative. Set NULL want apply rule. conf_lvl Confidence level confidence credibility intervals. Default 0.95 (.e. 95 % confidence interval). excel_path Intended users prefer work excel minimal work R. write output da excel file, provide path folder. instance, write current working directory, pass getwd().  excel file default named da.xlsx. control excel file name,  pass path ending desired filename suffixed .xlsx.  want export output excel file, pass NULL (default).

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
text: da returns data frame (invisibly) containing counts estimates related supported disproportionality estimators. row corresponds drug-event pair.

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
text: passed df (convertible ) data table least contain three  columns: report_id, drug event. data table contain one row  per reported drug-event-combination, .e. receiving single additional report  drug X event Y add one row table. single report  contained drug X event Y event Z, two rows added,  report_id drug rows. Column report_id must type  numeric character. Columns drug event must type character.  column group_by provided, can either numeric character.  can use df column names choosing, long  connect role name df_colnames-parameter.

title: Disproportionality Analysis — da
code: ### Run a disproportionality analysis  da_1 <-   tiny_dataset |>   da()  ### Run a disproportionality across subgroups list_of_colnames <-   list(     report_id = "report_id",     drug = "drug",     event = "event",     group_by = "group"   )   da_2 <-   tiny_dataset |>   da(df_colnames = list_of_colnames)  # If columns in your df have different names than the default ones, # you can specify the column names in the df_colnames parameter list:  renamed_df <-   tiny_dataset |>   dplyr::rename(ReportID = report_id)  list_of_colnames$report_id <- "ReportID"  da_3 <-   renamed_df |>   da(df_colnames = list_of_colnames)

title: Information component — ic
text: Calculates information component ("IC") credibility interval, used disproportionality analysis.

title: Information component — ic
code: ic(obs = NULL, exp = NULL, shrinkage = 0.5, conf_lvl = 0.95)

title: Information component — ic
text: obs numeric vector observed counts, .e. number reports selected drug-event-combination. Note shrinkage (e.g. +0.5) added inside function included . exp numeric vector expected counts, .e. number reports expected given comparator background. Note shrinkage (e.g. +0.5) added inside function included . shrinkage non-negative numeric value, added observed expected count. Default 0.5. conf_lvl Confidence level confidence credibility intervals. Default 0.95 (.e. 95 % confidence interval).

title: Information component — ic
text: tibble three columns (point estimate credibility bounds).

title: Information component — ic
text: IC log2-transformed observed--expected ratio, based relative reporting rate (RRR) counts, modified addition "shrinkage" protect spurious associations. $$\hat{IC} = log_{2}(\frac{\hat{O}+k}{\hat{E}+k})$$ \(\hat{O}\) = observed number reports, \(k\) shrinkage (typically +0.5), expected \(\hat{E}\) (RRR, using entire database comparator background) estimated $$ \hat{E} = \frac{\hat{N}_{drug} \times \hat{N}_{event}}{\hat{N}_{TOT}}$$ \(\hat{N}_{drug}\), \(\hat{N}_{event}\) \(\hat{N}_{TOT}\) number reports drug, event, whole database respectively. credibility interval created quantiles posterior gamma distribution shape (\(\hat{S}\)) rate (\(\hat{R}\)) parameters $$\hat{S} = \hat{O} + k$$ $$\hat{R} = \hat{E} + k$$ using stats::qgamma function. Parameter \(k\) shrinkage defined earlier. completeness, credibility interval gamma distributed \(X\) (.e. \(X \sim \Gamma(\hat{S}, \hat{R})\) \(\hat{S}\) \(\hat{R}\) shape rate parameters) associated quantile function \(Q_X(p)\) significance level \(\alpha\) constructed $$[Q_X(\alpha/2), Q_X(1-\alpha/2)]$$

title: Information component — ic
text: bayesian point--view, credibility interval IC constructed poisson-gamma conjugacy. shrinkage constitutes prior observed expected 0.5. shrinkage +0.5 gamma-quantile based 95 % credibility interval lower bound 0 unless observed count exceeds 3. One benefit \(log_{2}\) provide log-scale convenient plotting multiple IC values side--side.

title: Information component — ic
text: Norén GN, Hopstadius J, Bate (2011). “Shrinkage observed--expected ratios robust transparent large-scale pattern discovery.” Statistical Methods Medical Research, 22(1), 57--69. doi:10.1177/0962280211403604 , https://doi.org/10.1177/0962280211403604.

title: Information component — ic
code: ic(obs = 20, exp = 10) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   ic2.5    ic ic97.5 #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 0.264 0.965   1.53 # Note that obs and exp can be vectors (of equal length, no recycling allowed) ic(obs = c(20, 30), exp = c(10, 10)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   ic2.5    ic ic97.5 #>   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 0.264 0.965   1.53 #> 2 0.976 1.54    2.01

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
text: Calculates Proportional Reporting Rate ("PRR") confidence intervals, used disproportionality analysis.

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
code: prr(   obs = NULL,   n_drug = NULL,   n_event_prr = NULL,   n_tot_prr = NULL,   conf_lvl = 0.95 )

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
text: obs Number reports specific drug event (.e. observed count). n_drug Number reports drug interest. n_event_prr Number reports event background. n_tot_prr Number reports background. conf_lvl Confidence level confidence credibility intervals. Default 0.95 (.e. 95 % confidence interval).

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
text: tibble three columns (point estimate credibility bounds). Number rows equals length inputs obs, n_drug, n_event_prr n_tot_prr.

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
text: PRR proportion reports event set exposed cases, divided proportion reports event background comparator, include exposed. PRR estimated observed--expected ratio, based similar RRR IC, excludes exposure interest comparator. $$\hat{PRR} = \frac{\hat{O}}{\hat{E}}$$ \(\hat{O}\) observed number reports, expected \(\hat{E}\) estimated $$\hat{E} = \frac{\hat{N}_{drug} \times (\hat{N}_{event} - \hat{O})}{\hat{N}_{TOT}-\hat{N}_{drug}}$$ \(\hat{N}_{drug}\), \(\hat{N}_{event}\), \(\hat{O}\) \(\hat{N}_{TOT}\) number reports drug, event, drug event, whole database respectively. confidence interval derived Gravel (2009) using delta method: $$\hat{s} = \sqrt{ 1/\hat{O} - 1/(\hat{N}_{drug}) + 1/(\hat{N}_{event} - \hat{O}) - 1/(\hat{N}_{TOT} - \hat{N}_{drug})}$$ $$[\hat{CI}_{\alpha/2}, \hat{CI}_{1-\alpha/2}] = $$ $$[\frac{\hat{O}}{\hat{E}} \times \exp(Q_{\alpha/2} \times \hat{s}), \frac{\hat{O}}{\hat{E}} \times \exp(Q_{1-\alpha/2} \times \hat{s})]$$ \(Q_{\alpha}\) denotes quantile function standard Normal distribution significance level \(\alpha\). Note: historical reasons, another version standard deviation sometimes used last fraction square root added rather subtracted, negligible practical implications large databases. function uses version declared , .e. subtraction.

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
text: Montastruc J, Sommet , Bagheri H, Lapeyre-Mestre M (2011). “Benefits strengths disproportionality analysis identification adverse drug reactions pharmacovigilance database.” British Journal Clinical Pharmacology, 72(6), 905--908. doi:10.1111/j.1365-2125.2011.04037.x , https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2125.2011.04037.x. Gravel C (2009). “Statistical Methods Signal Detection Pharmacovigilance.” https://repository.library.carleton.ca/downloads/jd472x08w.

title: Proportional Reporting Rate — prr
code: prr(   obs = 5,   n_drug = 10,   n_event_prr = 20,   n_tot_prr = 10000 ) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   prr2.5   prr prr97.5 #>    <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1   117.   250    534.   # Note that input parameters can be vectors (of equal length, no recycling) pvda::prr(   obs = c(5, 10),   n_drug = c(10, 20),   n_event_prr = c(15, 30),   n_tot_prr = c(10000, 10000) ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   prr2.5   prr prr97.5 #>    <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  150.   333.    742. #> 2   94.7  167.    293.

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
text: Calculates Reporting Odds Ratio ("ROR") confidence intervals, used disproportionality analysis.

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
code: ror(a = NULL, b = NULL, c = NULL, d = NULL, conf_lvl = 0.95)

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
text: Number reports specific drug event (.e. observed count). b Number reports drug, without event c Number reports without drug, event d Number reports without drug, without event conf_lvl Confidence level confidence credibility intervals. Default 0.95 (.e. 95 % confidence interval).

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
text: tibble three columns (point estimate credibility bounds). Number rows equals length inputs , b, c, d.

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
text: ROR odds ratio calculated reporting counts. R Reporting ROR meant emphasize interpretation reporting, ROR calculated reporting database. Note: function vectorized, .e. , b, c d can vectors, see examples. reporting odds ratio simply odds ratio based adverse event reports. $$\hat{ROR} = \frac{/b}{c/d}$$ \(\) = observed count (.e. number reports exposure outcome), \(b\) = number reports drug without event, \(c\) = number reports without drug event \(d\) = number reports neither drug event. confidence interval ROR can derived delta method, standard deviation: $$\hat{s} = \sqrt{1/+ 1/b + 1/c + 1/d}$$ resulting confidence interval significance level \(\alpha\) $$[\hat{ROR} \times exp(\Phi_{\alpha/2} \times \hat{s}), \hat{ROR} \times exp(\Phi_{1-\alpha/2} \times \hat{s})]$$

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
text: Montastruc J, Sommet , Bagheri H, Lapeyre-Mestre M (2011). “Benefits strengths disproportionality analysis identification adverse drug reactions pharmacovigilance database.” British Journal Clinical Pharmacology, 72(6), 905--908. doi:10.1111/j.1365-2125.2011.04037.x , https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2125.2011.04037.x.

title: Reporting Odds Ratio — ror
code: ror(   a = 5,   b = 10,   c = 20,   d = 10000 ) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   ror2.5   ror ror97.5 #>    <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1   78.4   250    797.  # Note that a, b, c and d can be vectors (of equal length, no recycling) pvda::ror(   a = c(5, 10),   b = c(10, 20),   c = c(15, 30),   d = c(10000, 10000) ) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   ror2.5   ror ror97.5 #>    <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  102.   333.   1092. #> 2   72.0  167.    386.
